column3: I do take issue with delegates continuing to refer to the independence of the Revenue Commissioners and the need to defend it without noting that the Moriarty tribunal found that there was political interference. Because of the level of that political interference the House was required to introduce legislation to make it a crime. I ask the panel of delegates to comment on the fact that one of the largest accountancy firms in the State
column4: KPMG
column5: is advertising on its website as an "Irish headquartered company". It talks about the attraction of using Ireland as a global corporate headquarters. It cites a number of reasons
column6: including that Ireland is a gateway to Europe; that it is a member of the eurozone; that it has an English-speaking
column7: young
column8: dynamic and well educated workforce; that it has a single financial services regulatory authority
column9: a common law legal system and an attractive tax regime encompassing the rates of 0%
column11: depending on the vehicle used. Why do we have one of the largest accountancy firms in the country telling global giants to locate here and stating there are vehicles by which they could reduce their tax liabilities to zero? Do the delegates think that is the type of member state tax regime we should have in place in this jurisdiction? I ask Mr. Clarken to comment first.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	60	It is quite offensive to the citizens of Ireland that such an assertion is being made on behalf of all of us in the context of the investment that takes place here because of the things the Deputy mentioned. The benefits include that Ireland has an English-speaking
column2: well educated workforce
column3: as well as access to the European market. It is worth remembering that although we had a consistent tax rate for many years
column4: things did not really take off until the mid-1990s following the peace process
column5: when there was the investment of funds from the European Union in infrastructure. There was also the impact of investment in education over a long period. We understand there are global accountancy giants which are advocating and presenting Ireland in this very way. This goes to the heart of what we want in terms of the need for transparency. We cannot see a justifiable reason not to have absolute transparency and public country-by-country reporting in order that people in the media and others can scrutinise what is happening. Unless civil society can do the same in having public registers of beneficial ownership and the publication of tax rulings
column6: we will not have learned sufficiently from what has happened here and there is a real fear that it will continue in the future. We have not heard a single
column7: rational
column8: strong reason we are resisting providing for that level of transparency. We cannot rely on LuxLeaks
column9: the Panama papers and all of the solid pieces of investigative work by journalists to provide us with information which should be publicly available.

column1: #PearseDoherty	unknown-#PearseDoherty-party	unknown-#PearseDoherty-dob	unknown-#PearseDoherty-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	61	Will Dr. Stewart comment on the same matter?

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	62	It is wrong that the tax code allows certain vehicles to pay zero tax. The section 110 vehicle can offer very low rates of tax. In fact
column2: PwC also has a statement on its website that section 110 companies can also pay zero tax. That is wrong and needs to be addressed.

column1: #PearseDoherty	unknown-#PearseDoherty-party	unknown-#PearseDoherty-dob	unknown-#PearseDoherty-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	63	Will Mr. Keegan give us an explanation? We have legislation in place to deal with section 110 companies and will see how effective it is. Why is KPMG still promoting to companies that they should locate here as Irish-headquartered companies and that they can pay zero tax
column2: depending on the vehicle used?

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	64	Because
column2: in common with all businesses
column3: it wants more business. It is as simple as that. One of the points we can sometimes overlook - it is a commercial reality
column4: although I know that it is not a comfortable one for a lot of businesses - is that
column5: in my experience - I have been involved in the tax sector for 30 years - most businesses regard tax as another cost. It is a cost to be managed in the same way as manufacturing
column6: lighting or heating costs are managed. As a nation
column7: we have recognised this since the late 1950s. First there was export sales relief
column8: which was followed by the 10% manufacturing rate
column9: corporation tax from 1980 onwards and
column11: the 12.5% rate of corporation tax. When one is trying to attract business to a small peripheral country
column12: one uses whatever tools and levers one possibly can. It may not be acceptable in many quarters and I understand why. People are looking at their own tax bill and saying: "We have to pay so much. Why aren't other companies paying as much?" The reality is that businesses are more likely to migrate to where they can manage tax as a cost. Whether that is right or wrong is the subject of a separate discussion
column13: but I am answering the Deputy's question straight.  To give another point of view
column14: Dr. Stewart mentioned a justifiable reason for not having country-by-country reporting. The United States has indicated that it will not do business with any other country which provides for public country-by-country reporting. Why is it doing this? It is because it has a concern about confidentiality for its own corporates. I am not saying all of these things are right or wrong
column15: but I am trying to give a straight answer to the Deputy's question as to why a company such as KPMG might be advertising in this way. I have one last point to make about some of the structures used. Just because tax is not paid in Ireland does not necessarily mean that it is not ultimately paid somewhere else. That is a point worth making in the context of multinational tax planning.

column1: #PearseDoherty	unknown-#PearseDoherty-party	unknown-#PearseDoherty-dob	unknown-#PearseDoherty-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	65	I will put my last question to Mr. Clarken and Mr. Redmond.I am aware that on the day of the Apple ruling
column2: the CEO of a medical devices company operating here received a call from the CEO at the company's headquarters asking him whether the company had invested in the wild west. The CEO was concerned about the reputational damage that might ensue if Ireland was involved in practices of this nature. I ask Mr. Clarken
column3: who has spoken about the impact of reputational damage on other member states
column4: and Mr. Redmond to respond to that.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	66	Ireland is a very credible international player in international development
column2: human rights and social justice. Its voice is heard way above its scale and its size. The events of the last year or two have had a hugely detrimental impact on Ireland's reputation. It is important for corporations to remember that the tax euro they pay are needed not just for social services like health and the education of the kind of workforce they require
column3: but also for public investment in infrastructure like water and quality broadband. If they do not pay their taxes
column4: they will not have the capacity to do what they need to do here. It is very short-sighted for corporations to be unwilling to pay their fair share. If the US is not willing to engage with companies that have public country-by-country reporting
column5: we need to challenge it about that because the Inland Revenue Service in the US is also losing out. We mentioned in a report we produced for Davos less than a month ago that the eight wealthiest people in the world own the same amount of wealth as 3.6 billion people. The IMF
column6: the World Economic Forum and numerous other agencies that would ordinarily have nothing to do with our arguments have identified this as a global crisis that will have significant implications for economic growth across the world if it is not addressed. This problem must be addressed for the benefit of economies and multinational companies. If developing countries are not given an opportunity to move beyond their current stage of development
column7: they will not be able to create markets for the kinds of products and services these companies want to sell. This needs to be considered by such companies from a self-interest point of view. If this is managed properly
column8: it will result in a win for companies. Things cannot continue as they are at present.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	67	As I said at the outset
column2: we must remember when we use phrases like the "wild west" that we are talking about the reputations of 150
column3: 000 talented people in this country who work for US companies. The Deputy referred to a phone call between two leaders of a medical technology company. The recipient of the call is the leader of a team that is part of a group of people in this country who create four out of every five medical stents
column4: thereby saving lives throughout the world. These 150
column5: 000 bright people
column6: who are passionate about innovation
column7: would not do what they do to save and enhance lives if they were working in the wild west. We should be proud of them and proud of the contribution they are making to Ireland's reputation on the world stage.

Does Mr. Redmond have any reason to believe the representatives of Apple were telling lies to the Senate congressional committee? Would it not be a serious matter if members of the chamber of commerce swore under oath and lied to a Senate congressional committee? Would Mr. Redmond's assumption be that his members told the truth at the Senate congressional hearing when they said they believed there was a special tax arrangement with Ireland and when Tim Cook said there was a special tax incentive scheme? Does Mr. Redmond have any reason to believe they were stating anything other than the truth?

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	75	The point I would make about people looking on now is that there is an ongoing legal process. A decision will be made on the basis of the evidence. That is where we are right now. It would be wrong for me to interfere in that legal process.

#RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	76	Okay. I think any reasonable person looking at it would say the company has been caught with its pants down. It said something it believed to be true at the time
column2: but it decided to backtrack on that at a later point when it discovered that it was going to cost it dearly. I think that is what any reasonable person looking at this would conclude. We will move on. I think the point has been made. Professor Stewart said that in 2011
column3: Apple Sales International
column4: with "no employees
column5: no fixed assets and income of $22 billion" paid €10 million in tax. This equates to a tax rate of 0.045%
column6: or less than half of 1%. The company cannot have many overheads if it has no employees and no office. I want to clarify that it has no legal tax residence anywhere in the world. Regardless of the merits of the current case - I am not asking about them - do Mr. Redmond and Mr. Keegan consider that the facts I have outlined are acceptable? Is it acceptable that a company could make $22 billion in revenue while having no overheads and paying less than 1% in tax? Leaving aside the issue of Ireland
column7: do Mr. Keegan and Mr. Redmond believe that to be morally acceptable?

column4: to whatever extent
column5: in a society they must buy into the rules. Therefore
column6: they must be compliant with all of the rules of that society
column7: including the tax rules. That is a reasonable and coherent position. As for the first question on moral grounds-----

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	102	Once one gets over the moral issue of compliance

column5: is that it is not. That is why we have a thing called the base erosion and profit sharing
column6: BEPS

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	114	I spend a lot of my time trying to teach tax. From that point of view
column2: nothing would suit me better than a common consolidated corporate tax base
column3: CCCTB. It would be fantastic
column4: in theory
column5: to have a common system where everybody knew exactly where they stood in terms of taxation. The system has two fatal flaws. First
column6: because it would be centralised to Brussels it would not give Oireachtas Éireann the kind of flexibility it might need to change the situation to meet a different economic circumstance. Second
column7: because the tax arbitrage is all about mismatches and because CCCTB is effectively an EU-based system
column8: it does not address a huge part of the problem. I mean the mismatch between the likes of countries on the far side of the Atlantic and countries in the Far East. One has a local solution to a global problem. The upshot of that might be that those who are involved in the local solution might ultimately do this. Philosophically
column9: I have no particular difficulty with the scheme. My concerns about it are practical.

I commend Mr. Clarken and Dr. Stewart on the work of their organisations and their individual work in this whole area. Would Mr. Clarken from Oxfam agree it is fair to say that the major contributing factor to the staggering level of inequality he has identified in his recent report about eight people owning the same wealth as half the world's population is corporations that do not want to pay tax? I know there are lots of contributory factors. Would Mr. Clarken say that is the major contributing factor? What does he think we will be faced with if we do not address the problem in a serious manner in terms of redistributing the wealth that has become heavily concentrated at the top?  I shall ask Dr. Stewart a question as I am out of time. Perhaps both witnesses can answer together. I have read the TASC seminar report put together by Dr. Stewart and Mr. Cillian Doyle on the section 110 issue to which Dr. Stewart alluded earlier. The report is brilliant and quite shocking. Dr. Stewart has said that 2
column2: 500 financial vehicle corporations
column3: FVCs
column4: could be benefitting from the provisions of section 110
column5: which essentially is a scheme whereby no tax is paid on assets worth hundreds of billions of euro. If I have understood correctly what Dr. Stewart said - I ask him to confirm and elaborate slightly - there is little or no regulation on this area and there is not even joined-up thinking between the Central Bank and Revenue in terms of getting information on these firms. Dr. Stewart cited a range of stockbrokers
column6: financial organisations
column7: etc. that tout Ireland as a country without financial regulation and in which virtually no tax is paid on assets worth hundreds of billions of euro. I ask him to comment further on that point.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	120	I can answer the Deputy's question on impact. Without doubt
column2: tax avoidance of this scale has a massive impact and we know it amounts to €100 billion in developing countries. It amounts to trillions of euro when one considers individual wealth as well as corporation wealth that has not been taxed in the places that it should have been taxed. Let us remember
column3: as I have tried to illustrate
column4: the difference between a health service that works and one that works less well is people dying in huge numbers. Similarly
column5: it means children not being educated from the ages of five years upwards or children dying. That is how serious this problem is. I have outlined the human face and impact of tax avoidance. It has a massive impact on the lives of ordinary people across the world. Tax avoidance must resonate as a justice issue. We need global corporations to be successful
column6: innovative and produce great products and services in order that society at large will benefit.Corporations once thought of themselves as organisations that were to contribute to society as opposed to just quarterly reporting on profit improvements. As was quoted
column7: surely the moral contract with a society is the society where one is based. That is where it starts. When we see corporations in developing countries often not paying tax yet benefiting from the resources of that country
column8: whether they be natural or human resources
column9: and the benefits governments in those countries provide to them to make the money they want to make
column10: there is a complete mismatch. Our major concern is that the inequality growth we are seeing
column11: and it is important that people understand it is getting worse year on year
column12: is a huge impediment to development. We are fearful that it is an impediment to our ambition to eradicate extreme poverty
column13: which might sound like a big dream but if we continue at the pace we have been going in the past 20 years we could do that. There is a real concern
column14: and not just on the part of organisations like Oxfam but also the IMF
column15: the World Economic Forum and other such organisations
column16: that unless this is tackled head-on we will be looking at reversing some of the progress we have made rather than getting to the finish line. It has to be a priority for all of us.

column1: #RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	121	I thank Mr. Clarken.

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	122	I thank the Deputy for his question. Regarding section 110
column2: section 110 refers to this particular section in the 1997 Finance Act which underwrites an earlier provision. The basic idea was to encourage securitisation in the International Financial Services Centre
column3: IFSC. Rather confusingly
column4: there are two types of companies that may be section 110 companies. There are financial vehicle corporations
column5: FVCs
column6: that the Central Bank has been looking at for years and in which the European Central Bank
column7: ECB
column8: has been very interested
column9: and then special purpose vehicles
column11: that may benefit also under this provision. There are thousands of special purpose vehicles in Ireland
column12: only a small number of which are section 110 vehicles. An interesting aspect is that according to Revenue data
column14: 200 of these that are alive; they are trading. However
column15: according to Central Bank data there appears to be only about 1
column16: 650 so one of the issues Cillian Doyle and myself have been doing research on is to try to explain that gap. One of the possible reasons we have for explaining that gap is regulatory problems in locating an FVC and an SPV because it seems to us that the only way the Revenue finds out that a company is a section 110 company is when it is sending in its annual report and accounts. The Central Bank is supposed to collect this data within one week of anything trading but many companies do not seem to report to the Central Bank. Interestingly
column17: many of the companies that have bought distressed property are in the Central Bank registry as a FVC but they are not strictly an FVC. There are many other companies that are simply omitted. That area certainly deserves much more research. I hope that is helpful to the Deputy.

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	125	It is to the great credit of this country that little people
column2: generally speaking
column3: do not pay tax and bigger people do pay tax. The Deputy heard testimony from the Revenue Commissioners to the extent that approximately 40% of corporation is paid by fewer than a dozen companies. That principle also extends to our income tax system where
column4: effectively
column5: 75% of all income tax is paid by about 25% of wage earners. If a company of a sufficient size can operate in a multinational environment
column6: going back to the point I made earlier that companies regard tax as a cost and will do what they can legitimately to manage that cost
column7: it can put strategies in place that many of us cannot. American companies can put strategies in place that many European companies cannot because of a particular mismatch in the way tax is computed in both territories
column8: but that is the world in which we find ourselves. I do not believe it necessarily falls based on this case.

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	163	I think the committee is wrong. CCTB and CCCTB is a rational way of organising the intra-country allocation of profits. The OECD

column3: has gone down the route of setting prices at arm's length. Most trade that takes place in Ireland is within the firm and most of the trade takes place within the firm in monopolistic or oligopolistic-type structures
column4: such as Google and Apple. Determining the arm's length price is very difficult and subject to massive litigation. It is out of date and a formulary approach
column5: such as the CCTB
column6: is a much more rational way of organising that. By the way
column7: the tax rate in Ireland would remain the same. We could still have different tax rates.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	169	I suppose we have a number of issues with it and a number of reasons we specifically think this should be a global body. For example
column2: if Ireland was not a member of the OECD and suddenly this body decided to design a new system that we were not part of
column3: would we around here think it acceptable to join that after the rules had been created? More than 100 country Governments have been excluded from the agenda setting. I mentioned that at the start. I should have also said the OECD's processes are opaque. It has already determined that it will not be critical of countries within the club
column4: for example
column5: it has narrowly defined what a tax haven is. Understandably
column6: the OECD is committed to advancing the benefit to its members
column7: as opposed to the world which is what we think needs to happen
column8: and it has limited its agenda specifically to BEPS whereas a UN body could have a much broader remit. Also
column9: there is a lack of transparency and possibility to engage with and challenge the OECD on these processes
column10: compared with what a UN-mandated body would be obliged to do
column12: for media and for opposition to the various proposals that are being put forward. It is important that the membership involved in this matters. The OECD is based in Paris and developing countries have limited enough access to it. In the UN institutions
column13: the poorest countries are given financial support to participate where they do not necessarily have the technical or financial expertise or capacity to be involved. By definition
column14: it will be an unbalanced outcome. We have to acknowledge it is better than where we were but it is not the right vehicle.

column1: #MichaelWDArcy	unknown-#MichaelWDArcy-party	unknown-#MichaelWDArcy-dob	unknown-#MichaelWDArcy-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	170	We were the first country to move on the BEPS process. Some other countries within the OECD still have not moved. It was budget 2014 when we moved ahead of everybody else and we were told by the Department of Finance that there would be first-mover benefit. Did any first-mover benefit accrue to ourselves?

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	171	It is very difficult to know. I would also echo the previous speaker's statement that the BEPS project is not magic. It introduces a lot of complexities into the tax system. It makes what is already complex even more complex. There is also emphasis on exchange of information. Something has to be done with that information and there is a problem that revenue authorities in different countries may suffer from information overload. How can they deal with all the information on rulings and coming under country-by-country reporting so that they can use it in a particular way? There are greater chances of reform coming from the European Union rather than the OECD. In particular
column2: under changes in US Administration
column3: the US may become more hostile to the OECD process and may also engage in rather protective practices in tax
column4: trade and other policies.

column1: #MichaelWDArcy	unknown-#MichaelWDArcy-party	unknown-#MichaelWDArcy-dob	unknown-#MichaelWDArcy-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	172	Could the US leave the BEPS process?

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	173	I do not think it would leave the BEPS process but it could introduce unilaterally a lot of changes that would be at variance with the BEPS process. The risk is that other countries would feel that they have to retaliate or change their own.

column3: when she appeared before the committee last week
column4: said there could be €13 billion due to the Irish Exchequer. Is it possible that Ireland could have the benefit of the windfall of those moneys
column5: given that the information was given by the Revenue Commissioners on behalf of the State and that the reputational damage to Apple could be so much larger than €13 billion? Is it possible that a case could be taken by the company on the basis that the Revenue Commissioners gave an opinion it believed to be correct with regard to the law
column6: yet retrospectively the Commission moves with a state aid case that impacts on the company?

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	175	As I understand it
column2: what the European Commission has to prove is that not only did it give a ruling
column3: but it selected Apple for special treatment. There are two parts to it. I believe it is so important-----

column1: #MichaelWDArcy	unknown-#MichaelWDArcy-party	unknown-#MichaelWDArcy-dob	unknown-#MichaelWDArcy-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	176	I am putting it hypothetically.

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	177	I was not going to go there. That is best practice. That is why I said at the outset that I would hate to see any undermining of that in this context.

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	178	I will make two quick observations. In terms of information overload as a consequence of BEPS
column2: a common reporting standard has been developed. In fact
column3: the Oireachtas passed legislation in the Finance Act which allows the Revenue Commissioners not to accept voluntary disclosures any more with regard to offshore assets because the quality of the information they are getting is so good. I have to disagree completely with the observations on the BEPS process. As regards how the law should be applied
column4: I will make one observation to Deputy D'Arcy. The Revenue Commissioners were not saying this is how section 25 works. They were saying that they had a calculation to carry out of the actual commercial amount which falls subject to Irish tax. That is the issue. They have to give those types of decisions in all types of circumstances
column5: be they to multinationals or to a self-employed person who perhaps uses his car for private use and business. They constantly do this type of work and if we impede their capacity to clarify matters for taxpayers in any way
column6: we are doing ourselves a disservice.

column1: #MichaelWDArcy	unknown-#MichaelWDArcy-party	unknown-#MichaelWDArcy-dob	unknown-#MichaelWDArcy-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	179	What about the prospect of a case taken against the State on the basis that the information is given by the Revenue Commissioners to a company and subsequently a state aid case is taken?

column1: #RoseConwayWalsh	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-party	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-dob	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	181	I thank the witnesses for their presentations. column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	182	No

column1: #RoseConwayWalsh	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-party	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-dob	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	183	On that basis

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	184	It is not insignificant. It is a very important factor
column2: but

column1: #RoseConwayWalsh	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-party	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-dob	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	185	Imagine if absolutely no methodology was used and one could not trace anything. column3: indeed

column2: that is what the court proceedings will be about. It is to find out.

column3: to be helpful

column3: believing the reason multinationals are attracted to Ireland is that somehow we are more educated than the people of other countries does not hold true. column2: BEPS

column1: #RoseConwayWalsh	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-party	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-dob	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	205	I thank the American Chamber of Commerce Ireland for being here. column2: with headlines proclaiming fury at Apple’s 0.005% tax bill. column3: that it did not have tax fairness or transparency
column4: and that it lacked what I would call a progressive tax system? If we said we will do it right in the future
column5: would that not create absolute certainty for companies?

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	206	No. In short
column2: Ireland is not a tax haven. That is not just me saying it. It has been put on the record of this committee by Pierre Moscovici
column3: European Commissioner for Economic and Financial Affairs
column4: Taxation and Customs
column5: José Ángel Gurría
column6: the Secretary General of the OECD
column7: and Pascal Saint-Amans
column8: the leader of the OECD’s BEPS project. Tax havens do not have over 70 tax treaties and 20 information exchange agreements. column9: 000 people working and creating brilliant products and services which are saving and enhancing lives around the world. That is why I keep saying to the committee that we need to put the facts out about the substance and depth of the US-Ireland relationship.

column1: #RoseConwayWalsh	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-party	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-dob	unknown-#RoseConwayWalsh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	207	Absolutely. That goes without saying. I know figures fluctuate from here and there on direct and indirect investment and so forth. It is difficult to substantiate them but it is well-recognised we have a positive relationship with the US. We want to protect that in terms of investment both ways
column2: both from Ireland and back. We are just trying to get to the crux of fairness and tax justice. Mr. Clarken’s recent report labelled Ireland a tax haven
column3: which provoked much anger. What is the most internationally-recognised measure of what is and what is not a tax haven? Based on the OECD’s assessment
column4: how many tax havens are there in the world?

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	208	The OECD definition is limited. I will not engage in semantics but any destination which facilitates

column5: going back to the core argument
column6: there is a real global problem and Ireland is somehow part of it. column7: public beneficiaries of ownership or publication of tax rulings. Had it not been for the US Senate inquiry
column8: we would not be aware of the Apple situation? Without having the level of transparency needed
column9: we may see situations like this again
column10: with or without BEPs. This has to go to the heart of what needs to be done and transparency needs to be central.

column3: therefore

column3: that the bulk of the moneys will remain with Ireland.

column1: #PeterBurke	unknown-#PeterBurke-party	unknown-#PeterBurke-dob	unknown-#PeterBurke-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	217	I thank Senator Conway-Walsh. I have a few questions on the CCCTB proposal. In 2016 we had huge celebrations of our sovereignty. Does Dr. Stewart believe there is a danger that the CCCTB could water down or compromise our sovereignty and our ability to set our own tax rules?

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	218	I think that because Ireland has signed up to the treaties
column2: we have already voluntarily given up a lot of our sovereignty. We exchange a huge amount of information with the Commission and other EU countries. I think that is right and a good thing to do. There are enormous benefits from being in the EU and we have voluntarily given up considerable aspects of our sovereignty. It is a bit of a chimera to suggest that we have sovereignty over our tax. Our tax rate is heavily influenced by what other countries do. In the context of Brexit
column3: for example
column4: if the UK goes down the route of light-touch regulation and low corporate tax
column5: that will have huge adverse implications for us. What do we mean by sovereignty? How can we really be sovereign in setting our own tax rates? Co-operation and collaboration is a better economic strategy for us.

column1: #PeterBurke	unknown-#PeterBurke-party	unknown-#PeterBurke-dob	unknown-#PeterBurke-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	219	If Ireland were to agree to the proposal
column2: Dr. Stewart does not believe that it would compromise the Oireachtas in terms of setting tax rules. Is that correct? I ask Dr. Stewart to give me a "Yes" or "No" answer.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	220	Yes
column2: of course it would change it but-----

column1: #PeterBurke	unknown-#PeterBurke-party	unknown-#PeterBurke-dob	unknown-#PeterBurke-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	221	That is okay.
#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	222	-----to our benefit
column2: as with all of the other agreements with the EU which have been to our benefit.

column1: #PeterBurke	unknown-#PeterBurke-party	unknown-#PeterBurke-dob	unknown-#PeterBurke-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	223	The second point I want to pick up on relates to Dr. Stewart's response to Deputy Michael D'Arcy. He said that it does not change the rate of tax at which companies are charged.

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	224	I meant the CCTB. The initial stage would not change the rate.

#PeterBurke	unknown-#PeterBurke-party	unknown-#PeterBurke-dob	unknown-#PeterBurke-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	225	In terms of a company for which this would become mandatory and the capacity of the State to charge tax on a company's passive income and investment income
column2: the European Commission confirmed to this committee that the State could not charge a higher rate on that. Would Dr. Stewart agree with that?

column2: that is
column3: the common tax base. There would be other changes
column4: of course
column5: with the CCCTB because it would be based on a formal reapportionment.

column1: #PeterBurke	unknown-#PeterBurke-party	unknown-#PeterBurke-dob	unknown-#PeterBurke-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	227	The CCCTB would change the rate. Is that correct?
#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	228	No
column2: under CCTB we can still set the rate
column3: it just allocates the tax base-----

column1: #PeterBurke	unknown-#PeterBurke-party	unknown-#PeterBurke-dob	unknown-#PeterBurke-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	229	Can we charge tax at the higher rate on investment income and passive income?

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	230	I have not read anything to the contrary. Perhaps Mr. Keegan knows whether that is the proposal.

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	231	My understanding of the proposal is that we would be lumbered with one tax rate and could not distinguish any longer between passive income and trading income
column2: which would be a big disadvantage.

column1: #PeterBurke	unknown-#PeterBurke-party	unknown-#PeterBurke-dob	unknown-#PeterBurke-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	232	That is a huge point which was also made by the Commission in here. Given that Dr. Stewart is advocating that we do this
column2: is it not strange that he is not aware of that aspect of the proposal? The European Commission has given evidence to this committee and was very clear that countries will only be able to charge one rate and will not be able to charge a higher rate on certain income.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	233	There are lots of other aspects to CCTB involving deductions that can be made. There is talk about a deduction for equity in line with interest income
column2: so in terms of the actual proposal that will come out
column3: it is all to play for. A lot of negotiation has yet to take place.

There is the forecast by Ernst & Young but that could change in terms of the amount of assets available in Ireland. That is a forecast.

My final point relates to the current mismatch in terms of countries outside Europe. Will the CCCTB have any influence on that or change anything in that regard?

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	237	I am sorry but I do not quite understand the Deputy's question-----

#PeterBurke	unknown-#PeterBurke-party	unknown-#PeterBurke-dob	unknown-#PeterBurke-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	238	I am asking about the mismatch when Ireland is dealing with other countries. To take the Apple case
column2: there is a mismatch of international tax legislation. Does Dr. Stewart believe that these proposals would do anything to change that?

#PeterBurke	unknown-#PeterBurke-party	unknown-#PeterBurke-dob	unknown-#PeterBurke-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	240	Yes.

column2: but not with a third country.

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	247	There would still be a problem but I think that-----

column3: obviously the law has changed here since then but in terms of the major international mismatch
column4: a lot more work has to be done to solve that
column5: rather than narrowly focusing on one EU proposal.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	249	I would be surprised if the Commission did not play a more active part in negotiating between those countries which had a common CCTB and those outside the EU.

#PeterBurke	unknown-#PeterBurke-party	unknown-#PeterBurke-dob	unknown-#PeterBurke-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	250	Finally
column2: I have a question for Mr. Keegan. When we hear the term "deals" being used in the media
column3: very loosely in some cases
column4: with regard to the Apple case
column5: does that compromise Revenue's authority to issue advance opinions? Obviously investors and taxpayers need to rely on advance opinions
column6: in terms of their interpretation of the law and in terms of certainty.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	251	Inevitably - as a result of human nature
column2: if nothing else - it has made Revenue an awful lot more cautious. We have seen in recent times a number of changes to Revenue's procedures around advance opinions
column3: most notably in the last few weeks where Revenue has time-bound future opinions and any opinions post-2012 to a period of five years. A sunset clause has been put in place. That
column4: of itself
column5: is not necessarily a bad thing. One of the other points that generally applies is that we do not rely terribly heavily on advance opinions in Ireland in comparison with other European countries because our tax system is fundamentally different. It is based on common law principles rather than civil law principles. Looking at the judgment
column6: there is a mismatch there in the tradition of tax and perhaps a misunderstanding. To respond directly to the Deputy's question
column7: it is bound to have had an effect.

column1: #PeterBurke	unknown-#PeterBurke-party	unknown-#PeterBurke-dob	unknown-#PeterBurke-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	252	When Commissioner Vestager appeared before this committee
column2: she insisted that the sovereignty of this country was not being watered down by her decision to impose state aid rules and to take this case. She was very clear that the Commission was not encroaching on our laws. Is there anything in the various tax consolidation Acts that can be used to collect this tax from Apple?

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	253	I think that Revenue has an enormous procedural difficulty in raising an assessment for tax that it already judged is not due and collectible in this country. I cannot see any of the normal provisions applying in this instance.

#PeterBurke	unknown-#PeterBurke-party	unknown-#PeterBurke-dob	unknown-#PeterBurke-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	254	I heard a tax expert on radio recently who said that the company submitted its tax return in compliance with the law and that in this case there was also an advance opinion to back that up. The Commission is using state aid rules as a vehicle to collect this tax. Is that correct?
#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	255	That is correct.

#PeterBurke	unknown-#PeterBurke-party	unknown-#PeterBurke-dob	unknown-#PeterBurke-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	256	That is a very clear case of the Commission superseding Irish tax law
column2: in the context of the method being used to collect the tax.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	257	That is a conclusion that one would have to draw and that is why
column2: in the European treaties
column3: there is a very clear distinction made between what the Commission can do on fiscal matters
column4: and tax matters specifically
column5: and what it can do on state aid matters. One of the contentions right the way along
column6: in terms of the arguments against the Commission and in terms of the practicalities
column7: is that this is state aid going beyond its normal boundaries. We are quite used to state aid rules influencing the construction of Irish law and to getting Irish law pre-cleared under those rules. This is state aid impinging on an administrative decision by an arm of the State and that is unprecedented.

column1: #PeterBurke	unknown-#PeterBurke-party	unknown-#PeterBurke-dob	unknown-#PeterBurke-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	258	It is unprecedented in terms of tax in Ireland too.
#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	259	That is correct.

#PeterBurke	unknown-#PeterBurke-party	unknown-#PeterBurke-dob	unknown-#PeterBurke-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	260	Finally
column2: how does Mr. Keegan see the BEPS process working in terms of the exchange of information? I ask Mr. Keegan to comment on the fact that Ireland is undertaking a corporate tax review
column3: as announced in the budget. I also invite him to comment on the loopholes that have been closed off
column4: including the so-called double Irish relating to stateless companies that are incorporated within the Companies Registration Office
column5: CRO
column6: the section 110 companies and so forth. What are his views on how the Government has responded in this budget to ensure that our tax system is transparent and that loopholes that were being used in an inappropriate manner are closed off?

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2017-02-07 00:00:00	EU State Aid Investigations into Tax Rulings (resumed)	261	Our history of responding
column2: in particular to the BEPS project
column3: has been absolutely outstanding. We talk about our conflict
column4: for want of a better word
column5: with the European Commission at the moment but a range of directives have been brought into play
column6: in terms of information exchange and co-operation in the recovery of taxes across borders
column7: which Ireland has signed up to with some alacrity. The consequence of that has been that the system has become progressively more and more insulated from attack and the consequence of that has been that the corporation tax yield has gone up by 50% in the last two years. We are going in the right direction.As I expressed earlier to Deputy Michael McGrath
column8: I am a bit concerned about the consequences of this case for the best process overall. Even prior to the inauguration of President Trump
column9: the US authorities already seemed to be beginning to push back on some of the developments and this is clearly not helping.
